posts.name: Thomas "Owen" Mattarocchia
posts.cooked: Hello, a team 3939 member here. Recently, I started moving toward cad (SOLIDWORKS) designing our robot in response to senior members leaving this year. Usually I am able to create a part needed on the robot, however, I am unsure how to correctly plan a robot on cad. My original thought process was to put 2 extra surface planes that I could put my plans on directly. Upon further outlook though, it seems this wasn’t the best way to do things. Could someone enlighten me on how either them or their team do this? Thanks!

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked:
There a bunch of ways to approach this, but generally an easy starting point is to create a blocky concept model, usually called crayon or crayola CAD, that outlines all the space claims for each mechanism. Create individual parts to represent each mechanism with somewhat accurate dimensions and little detail except for what’s necessary; just the silouette. Mate the parts together to create a bot-shaped object that you can reference later. Solidworks has advanced mating tools as well for more complex mechanical motion.

A lot of teams also use master sketches solely or in conjunction with crayon CAD, although this can vary in usefulness depending on the level of detail you can pull directly out of thin air. Often I’ve found that crayon comes first, and then use master sketches in assemblies and subassemblies to work out complex geometry.

edit: Additional thought, when you start going through in a more detailed design pass, it’s common to start with the drivebase and move up. Think about how your bot might be assembled, and model in that direction.
254’s explanation here is an excellent writeup and a pretty good start to learn the whole design process.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Adding to the other great comments, it’s reasonable to expect to refactor your design as well. Either by cleaning up and changing structure inside the original file, or starting from scratch and recreating the geometry in a cleaner feature tree. That could be more painful on a large shared project, but it is manageable especially if you are compartmentalizing the designs.

My approach with SolidWorks in this case is to keep revision names in the file names of top level parts/assemblies. Most files stop at revA, but some will get all the way to revD on a single design push if there’s lots of ways to solve the problem. All that is to say, start capturing your ideas, and don’t stress over perfection in your file. You should plan to come back and name your features, or reorganize, or fully dimension sketches. Best practices don’t have to be there on your first pass.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: I generally start with a ton of sketches and use those to create the most critical parts first. Usually for FRC , that’s DT and elex (which is usually represented by a ton of boxes because I am not cadding elex). Then I go on to mechanisms which is generally data obtained from prototyping teams. Nowadays when most of my cad work is for projects where I’m doing 90% of the mechanical design and prototyping and such I usually make a list of requirements and look at previous solutions, once I get there I make a drawing on my iPads notes app before even touching Solidworks.

posts.name: Thomas "Owen" Mattarocchia
posts.cooked:
banjogates:

There a bunch of ways to approach this, but generally an easy starting point is to create a blocky concept model, usually called crayon or crayola CAD, that outlines all the space claims for each mechanism.

Understood! I’m checking out Crayola CAD right now, I am using this video to better figure Crayola cad out. From a first outlook it looks similar to what I was attempting just way better structured. Thanks for the help!

CelestialMaelstrom:

254’s explanation here is an excellent writeup and a pretty good start to learn the whole design process.

Sounds good! From a first impression I do like the idea of illustrating the robot from a side profile on cad, as I am not much of an artist with cad drawings.

theworkshope:

My approach with SolidWorks in this case is to keep revision names in the file names of top level parts/assemblies. Most files stop at revA, but some will get all the way to revD on a single design push if there’s lots of ways to solve the problem.

Thanks! Ill be sure to implement this into my design process!

gellnick:

I generally start with a ton of sketches and use those to create the most critical parts first. Usually for FRC , that’s DT and elex (which is usually represented by a ton of boxes because I am not cadding elex). Then I go on to mechanisms which is generally data obtained from prototyping teams.

Understood! I was unsure where to start first so this helps a lot!
